title: Is artificial intelligence mostly just deep learning? - Quora

response.answer_text: No, AI is about much more. The best way to think about it is to see AI as a set of problems (how do we make machines that behave like humans) and deep learning as one approach (certainly not the only one) to tackling them. There are many other problems that are part of AI. For example, symbolic reasoning (e.g. “is Donald Trump taller than Obama” or “who has right of way at this intersection given the rules”) is an entire subfield that deep learning really hasn’t tackled. For that, there are entirely different approaches (either Probabilistic or logical) and systems for making logical deductions.

Intelligence is the ability of a system to calculate, reason, perceive relationships and analogies, learn from experience, store and retrieve information from memory, solve problems, comprehend complex ideas, use natural language fluently, classify, generalize, and adapt new situations[1]. Different components of intelligence are:  Source[2] Artificial Intelligence (AI) pertains to algorithms and techniques that can act like a human when performing cognitive functions (e.g. decision making). Analogous to learning, machine learning (ML) is one of the components of an AI system. And deep learning is one way of doing ML. For more information please refer to: What are the main differences between artificial intelligence and machine learning? Is machine learning a part of artificial intelligence?What is the relationship between machine learning, deep learning, artificial intelligence, artificial neural network and genetic algorithms?What's the difference between the terms "machine learning", "deep learning", and "AI"?Footnotes[1] Artificial Intelligent Systems[2] Image on tutorialspoint.com
